arm_group.description: Patients received intravenously saline solution at 5 ml/Kg/h
Patients received intravenously saline solution at 5 ml/Kg/h and dopamine at 3 mcg/Kg/min
Patients received intravenously saline solution at 10 ml/Kg/h

brief_summary.textblock:
Aim of this study was to investigate the cardiac and renal responses to the administration
      of different amount of crystalloids, with and without dopamine, during gynaecological
      laparoscopic surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  ASA I

          -  age 24-42

          -  patients undergoing gynaecological laparoscopy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  cardiovascular diseases

          -  renal and endocrine disorders

          -  obesity (BMI > 30 Kg/m2)

          -  the assumption of drugs that could interfere with renal parameters considered in the
             study

facility.name: Catholic University of the sacred Heart

clinical_study.official_title: Dopamine Infusion and Crystalloids Administration Improve Renal Function During Laparoscopic Surgery

primary_outcome.description: EGFr, tissue Doppler imaging and E/Ea are registered after the induction of pneumoperitoneum and Trendelemburg position, and compared to those registered before the induction of anesthesia.
primary_outcome.measure: estimated glomerular filtration rate, tissue Doppler imaging, E/Ea
primary_outcome.time_frame: patients will be followed for the duration of surgery, an expected average of 3 hours

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Catholic University of the Sacred Heart

secondary_outcome.description: TID will be measured at the end of surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: patients will be followed for the duration of surgery, an expected average of 3 hours

clinical_study.source: Catholic University of the Sacred Heart

lead_sponsor.agency: Catholic University of the Sacred Heart

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Treatment
